Table 5 Catalyst Co/Al2O3–CaO Co–5 K/Al2O3–CaO Co–10 K/Al2O3–CaO Co–15 K/Al2O3–CaO CO conversion (%) 87 66 65 62 CH4 yield (%) 81 26 15 10 CO2 yield (%) 19 27 30 29 Hydrogen production by the steam reforming of ethanol over K-promoted Co/Al2O3–CaO xerogel catalysts Sangbeom Yoo Conceptualization Methodology Investigation Writing - original draft Seungwon Park Investigation Ji Hwan Song Investigation Do Heui Kim Supervision Writing - review & editing * School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Institute of Chemical Processes, Seoul National University, 1 Gwanak-ro, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, 08826, South Korea School of Chemical and Biological Engineering Institute of Chemical Processes Seoul National University 1 Gwanak-ro, Gwanak-gu Seoul 08826 South Korea 1 School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Institute of Chemical Processes, Seoul National University, 1 Gwanak-ro, Gwanak-gu, Seoul, 08826, South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract After K doping on Co/Al2O3-CaO catalyst, methanation of CO (side reaction) was suppressed and higher hydrogen yield could be achieved from ethanol steam reforming. A series of K-promoted cobalt catalysts supported on Al2O3–CaO xerogel supports with different K loading (Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO, x = 0, 5, 10, and 15 wt.%, at fixed Co loading of 15 wt.%) were prepared to apply for ethanol steam reforming (ESR). K-promoted catalysts showed higher hydrogen yield and lower methane selectivity than did unpromoted catalyst. The promotion effect of K was investigated using various analyses, such as N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray Diffraction (XRD), H2–Temperature-Programmed Reduction (H2–TPR), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and Temperature-Programmed Surface Reaction (TPSR). Also, the catalysts were applied to methanation reaction, which is the main undesired reaction. It was found that lower methane selectivity during ESR over K-promoted catalysts was explained by the suppression effect of K on the methanation reaction. Also, TPSR study revealed that after K doping, starting temperature of the ESR shifted to lower temperature. However, excess amount of K doping blocked small pores of the alumina–calcium support, resulting in deterioration of the textural property of the catalysts. In addition, XPS analysis showed that as the amount of K doping increased, amount of surface concentration of cobalt decreased. Therefore, 10 wt.% K was found to be optimum loading for the ESR. Keywords Ethanol steam reforming Hydrogen production Co–K/Al2O3–CaO catalyst K doping Methanation 1 Introduction Fossil fuels have been the most abundantly used energy source worldwide. In fact, about 80 % of global energy is produced from fossil fuels, such as petroleum, coal, and natural gas [1]. However, since conventional fossil fuels are finite resources, exploiting clean and renewable energy sources has become a highly critical issue [2]. Hydrogen energy is one of the possible candidates for replacing fossil energy, because it does not produce any harmful pollutants, in addition to the high energy density per mass [3]. Hydrogen is mostly produced from the reforming of hydrocarbons. Specifically, steam reforming of natural gas is most frequently used for hydrogen production [4]. However, from the viewpoint of sustainability, the use of non-fossil feedstock, such as ethanol, for steam reforming reaction can be more advantageous. Ethanol is a non-toxic chemical, and can be produced from the fermentation of biomass. In addition, it exists in liquid state at room temperature (RT), so that it is easy to store and transport [5,6]. Theoretically, the only products of ethanol steam reforming reaction should be hydrogen and carbon dioxide. However, ethanol steam reforming reaction is composed of multiple step reactions and undesirable side reactions. It is known that the reaction mechanism may vary depending on the type of catalyst, but the most widely accepted reaction pathway for ethanol steam reforming is described below [7,8]: (1) C2H5OH ↔ C2H4O + H2 (2) C2H4O + H2O ↔ 2CO + 3H2 (3) C2H5OH ↔ CH4 + CO + H2 (4) C2H5OH ↔ C2H4 + H2O (5) CO + 3H2 ↔ CH4 + H2O (6) CH4 + H2O ↔ CO + 3H2 (7) 2CO ↔ CO2 + C (8) CO + H2O ↔ CO2 + H2 The first step of the reaction is the dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde (Eq. (1)), and sequential steam reforming of acetaldehyde yields carbon monoxide and hydrogen (Eq. (2)) [9]. Finally, water gas shift reaction produces additional hydrogen (Eq. (8)) [10]. In the real situation, there are additional side reactions. Previous research found that the acidic sites of catalysts can promote the dehydration of ethanol (Eq. (4)) [11,12]. Ethylene can be produced from this reaction, and the subsequent polymerization of ethylene leads to the formation of coke [13]. Methane is one of the major byproducts from ethanol steam reforming reaction, and it can be produced from the ethanol decomposition reaction (Eq. (3)) or methanation reaction (Eq. (5)). Methane is a very stable hydrocarbon, and the steam reforming of methane (Eq. (6)) requires higher temperature than the steam reforming of ethanol [14]. Finding catalysts that suppress the formation of ethylene and methane is very important to perform the steam reforming of ethanol with high selectivity to H2. Catalysts for ethanol steam reforming should have the ability to break the C–C bond. Noble metal catalysts, such as Rh, Ru, Pt, and Pd, are excellent catalysts for C–C bond cleavage [15]. However, due to their high price, transition metal catalysts, such as Ni or Co catalysts, are frequently used for ethanol steam reforming. Co catalyst is the more active catalyst for this reaction, because it produces much less methane than does Ni catalyst [16]. Usually, cobalt nanoparticles are supported on supporting materials, because unsupported cobalt nanoparticles lose catalytic activities at high temperature due to sintering [17]. One of the most widely used supports for Co catalysts is γ-Alumina, because of its high surface area and thermal stability [18]. However, since dehydration of ethanol occurs on the acidic sites of alumina support, the catalyst loses its activity, due to coke formation. Therefore, basic metals, such as alkali metals or alkaline earth metals, are incorporated into the alumina support, in order to suppress coke formation. Alkali metals have been applied as promoters for catalysts in steam reforming reaction. Specifically, some research reported the promoting effect of K in steam reforming reaction. In K–Ni–Cu–Mg–Ce–O/Al2O3 catalyst, K was found to adjust the Ni/Ni2+ ratio and surface acid–base properties. Methanation reaction was suppressed, and after the addition of K, the water–gas shift reaction was promoted [19]. For the case of Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, K was found to increase ethanol steam reforming activity by destabilizing surface acetate group [20]. Also, it is well known that alkali metals play a crucial role in enhancing catalytic activity in steam reforming reaction, by neutralizing the acidic sites of alumina support. Previously, our group studied the effect of calcium doping on Co/Al2O3 xerogel catalyst, and found that the production of ethylene was suppressed at the optimum amount of calcium doping [21]. Thus, in order to investigate the role of K in the reactivity of the Co catalyst, Al2O3–CaO support with the optimum loading of Ca was used. In this work, a series of Co–K/Al2O3–CaO xerogel catalysts with different K loading were prepared, and applied to the ethanol steam reforming reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts A series of mesoporous Co–K/Al2O3–CaO xerogel catalysts were prepared by using the following methods. Al2O3–CaO mixed oxide support was prepared via an epoxide-driven sol–gel method. 6 g of aluminum precursor (aluminum nitrate nonahydrate, Junsei, 98 %) and 1.9 g of calcium precursor (calcium nitrate tetrahydrate, Junsei, 98 %) were dissolved in absolute ethanol (30 mL). Transparent solution was obtained after vigorous stirring, and 15 mL of propylene oxide (Samchun, 99 %) was introduced into the solution for gelation. Al2O3–CaO composite gel was obtained after a few minutes, and the gel was aged at RT for 2 days. The gel was dried in a convection oven at 80 °C for 5 days, and then ground into powder. The samples were calcined at 750 °C to reduce formation of calcium carbonate. The furnace temperature was elevated to 750 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C/min, and it was kept for 5 h in air condition. Co–K/Al2O3–CaO catalysts were prepared by using wetness impregnation method. 0.74 g of cobalt precursor (cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, Junsei, 98 %) and a known amount of potassium precursor (potassium nitrate, Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %) were dissolved in deionized water (20 mL). Al2O3–CaO support (1 g) was introduced to the aqueous solution, and heated to 80 °C. Powder was obtained after evaporation process, which was dried in a convection oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The resultant was calcined with the same procedure used for the support. The prepared catalysts were denoted as Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15), where x represented the weight percent of potassium, while the amount of cobalt was fixed to 15 wt.%. 2.2 Characterization Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were acquired with a BELSORP-mini II (BEL Japan) device, and surface areas of the catalysts were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) method. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted in a D-Max2500-PC (Rigaku) instrument using Cu–Kα radiation (λ =1.541 Å, 50 kV, 100 mA). Scherrer equation was applied to calculate the mean crystal size of cobalt. H2–TPR profiles were obtained by gas chromatography (ACME 6000, Younglin). Catalysts (50 mg) were pretreated under flow of nitrogen (20 mL/min) at 600 °C for 1 h in a U-shaped quartz reactor. After pretreatment process, the furnace temperature was increased to 800 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C /min under mixed flow of nitrogen (20 mL/min) and hydrogen (2 mL/min). Hydrogen consumption was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted by VG Multilab 2000 spectrometry (Thermo Electron Corporation) with Al Kα X-ray source (1,486.6 eV). TPSR profiles were acquired by GC–MSD (6890 N GC-5975MSD, Agilent). Catalysts (50 mg) were reduced under mixed flow of helium (30 mL/min) and hydrogen (3 mL/min) at 750 °C for 1 h. Deionized water and ethanol were mixed with molar ratio of 6:1. After cooling temperature to 150 °C, the mixed solution was injected to the reactor by syringe pump at a flow rate of 0.2 mL/h. Finally, the furnace temperature was increased to 750 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C /min under flow of helium (10 mL/min), and gas composition was analyzed by GC–MSD. 2.3 Steam reforming of ethanol The prepared Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts were applied to the steam reforming of ethanol reaction using continuous flow fixed-bed reactor. Catalyst (100 mg) was pre-reduced at 750 °C for 1 h under a mixed flow of hydrogen (3 mL/min) and nitrogen (30 mL/min). After purging with nitrogen flow (30 mL/min) for 30 min, the reaction was carried out at 450 °C for 1,000 min under atmospheric pressure. Deionized water and ethanol was mixed with molar ratio of 6:1 (S/C ratio = 3), and the mixture was injected into the reactor using syringe pump at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/h. Nitrogen (30 mL/min) was used as a carrier gas, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was maintained at 23,140 mL/h·g. The products were analyzed by gas chromatography (ACME 6000, Younglin) by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Molecular Sieve 5A and Porapak N columns were used for product analysis. Ethanol conversion, hydrogen yield and byproduct selectivity were calculated using the following equations, where Fi, Si, and ni represent the flow rate, selectivity, and stoichiometric factor for carbon-containing byproducts, respectively. E t h a n o l c o n v e r s i o n % = F E t O H , i n - F E t O H , o u t F E t O H , i n × 100 H y d r o g e n y i e l d % = F H 2 3 × F E t O H , i n - F E t O H , o u t × 100 S i % = n i × F i 2 × ( F E t O H , i n - F E t O H , o u t ) × 100 2.4 Methanation reaction of carbon monoxide The prepared Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts were applied to the methanation reaction of carbon monoxide using continuous flow fixed-bed reactor. Catalyst (100 mg) was pre-reduced at 750 °C for 1 h under a mixed flow of hydrogen (3 mL/min) and nitrogen (30 mL/min). After purging with nitrogen flow (30 mL/min) for 30 min, the reaction was carried out at 450 °C for 15 h under atmospheric pressure. Mixed flow of carbon monoxide (1 mL/min) and hydrogen (6 mL/min) was injected into the reactor, and nitrogen (30 mL/min) was used as carrier gas. Considering the effluent gas composition of the ethanol steam reforming reaction, the methanation reaction was carried out in a hydrogen-rich condition. The products were analyzed by gas chromatography (ACME 6000, Younglin) with TCD. Molecular Sieve 5A and Porapak N columns were used for product analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of the calcined catalysts Nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurements were carried out to examine the textural properties of Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts calcined at 750 °C. Fig. 1 shows that all catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms, which can be explained by the capillary condensation in mesopores [22]. Also, all isotherms could be classified as type-H3 hysteresis loop. Thus, it can be inferred that slit-shaped pores (plates or edged particles, like cubes) were formed after calcination [23]. Table 1 summarizes the detailed textural properties of the calcined catalysts. The BET method was applied to calculate the specific surface area of the catalysts. All catalysts retained large pore diameter in the mesopore range of 2 to 50 nm after calcination, indicating that mesoporous structure was formed [24]. Surface area gradually decreased from 60 m2/g to 36 m2/g as potassium loading increased to 15 wt.%, whereas average pore diameter increased from 11.4 nm to 16.6 nm. From these phenomena, it can be claimed that potassium preferentially blocked small pores of alumina–calcium support [25]. 3.2 Crystalline structures of the calcined catalysts XRD analysis was performed in order to investigate the crystalline structures of Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts calcined at 750 °C. Fig. 2 shows that diffraction peaks at 31.3°, 36.8°, 59.4°, and 65.4° arising from the cubic spinel structure of cobalt oxide species were detected [26]. Since the catalysts were calcined at high temperature, some cobalt species could be incorporated into the alumina lattice to form CoAl2O4 [27]. However, it is difficult to distinguish Co3O4 and CoAl2O4 by the XRD peaks, because they both have the same cubic spinel structure. Diffraction peaks from potassium carbonate or potassium oxide were not observed, so it can be assumed that potassium species were highly dispersed on the alumina–calcium support. 3.3 Reducibility of the calcined catalysts H2–TPR measurements were conducted in order to explore the reducibility of Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts calcined at 750 °C. Carbonate species have been reported to release CO2 to form oxide species at around 600 °C [28]. Fig. S1 shows the TPR profile of Co/Al2O3–CaO obtained by GC–MSD without pretreatment, which demonstrated the evolution of CO2 at 600 °C. Thus, the catalysts were pretreated under flow of nitrogen (20 mL/min) at 600 °C for 1 h. Fig. 3 presents the TPR profiles, where two reduction peaks are observed. The literature assigned the low temperature peak located between 400 °C and 600 °C to the two-step reduction of Co3O4 to metallic cobalt, while attributing the high temperature peak located between 700 °C and 900 °C to the reduction of CoAl2O4 to cobalt metal [29]. As the amount of potassium loading increased, the temperature of the first peak increased from 500 °C to 570 °C, which other authors have similarly observed [30–32]. They claimed that potassium suppressed the reduction of cobalt by inhibiting the dissociative adsorption of hydrogen on cobalt [32,33]. Interestingly, potassium did not affect the position of the second reduction peak. It can be inferred that potassium doping did not affect the reducibility of stable cobalt oxide species strongly interacting with alumina support. 3.4 Characterization of the reduced catalysts Since metallic cobalt is the active site for the ethanol steam reforming, characterizations of reduced catalysts were conducted. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts reduced at 750 °C for 1 h. Diffraction peaks at 44.3°, 51.5°, and 75.9° arising from the face-centered cubic (fcc) phase of metallic cobalt were observed, while diffraction peaks for Co3O4 or CoO were not detected [34]. This indicates that all catalysts were fully reduced to metallic cobalt state during the reduction process. The mean crystallite sizes of metallic cobalt that were calculated from the fcc Co (1 1 1) peak using the Scherrer equation. Table 2 summarizes the calculated crystallite sizes to be in the range 16 nm to 18 nm. This means that there were no distinct differences in the average sizes of metallic cobalt as a function of the potassium loading. XPS analysis was conducted to measure the surface atomic compositions of the Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts reduced at 750 °C for 1 h. Table 3 summarizes that with increasing potassium loading, the surface atomic ratio of cobalt drastically decreased. Surface concentration was different from bulk concentration; the amount of potassium exposed at the surface was much larger than that of cobalt. Amorphous potassium oxide layer has been reported to be formed over cobalt metal species after H2 treatment [35]. Therefore, large amount of potassium could cover active cobalt surface species, resulting in the decrease of the surface atomic ratio of cobalt [36]. 3.5 Temperature Programmed Surface Reaction (TPSR) of the reduced catalysts TPSR of ethanol and water were performed to investigate the reactivity of Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts reduced at 750 °C for 1 h. Fig. 5 presents the distribution of ethanol (m/z = 31) as a function of temperature. As the temperature increased, ethanol signal started to disappear, which meant that steam reforming of ethanol was initiated. As potassium loading increased, complete conversion of ethanol was achieved at lower temperature from 450 °C to 425 °C. Such phenomena were similarly reported by other researchers. Espinal et al. applied cobalt hydrotalcites catalysts to ethanol steam reforming reaction, and observed that after potassium doping, the reaction occurred at lower temperature [37]. Since the first step of the reaction is the dehydrogenation of ethanol, potassium could play a crucial role in enhancing the dehydrogenation reaction of ethanol over cobalt metal. 3.6 Hydrogen production by the steam reforming of ethanol Fig. 6 shows the hydrogen yield with time on stream in the steam reforming of ethanol using Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = 0, 5, 10, and 15) catalysts at 450 °C. Table 4 summarizes the detailed catalytic performance of the catalysts in the ethanol steam reforming after a 1,000 min reaction. All catalysts retained stable catalytic activity during 1,000 min reaction, and 100% ethanol conversion was achieved for all catalysts. According to the literature, two types of coke can be generated during ethanol steam reforming. Encapsulating coke can be formed from the condensation of ethylene, while filamentous coke is produced from the disproportionation of CO (2CO → CO2 + C) or methane decomposition (CH4 → C + 2H2) [38]. Encapsulating coke is detrimental to catalysts, because it can block the active sites of the catalysts. It is well known that ethylene, the precursor of encapsulating coke, is produced from the dehydration of ethanol, which is promoted when the catalyst contains acidic sites [11]. In this research, the acidic sites were neutralized by alkali or alkaline earth metal, so during the steam reforming of ethanol, the production of encapsulating carbon was expected to be prevented. In contrast, filamentous coke does not interrupt the adsorption of ethanol on metal sites [39]. Thus, deactivation of the catalyst was not observed during 1,000 min reaction, even though high amount of coke was formed, which was confirmed by color change of the catalyst to black. After K doping, the hydrogen yield increased from 160% to 175%. Hydrogen yield decreased in the order Co–10 K/Al2O3–CaO > Co–5 K/Al2O3–CaO ≥ Co–15 K/Al2O3–CaO > Co/Al2O3–CaO. C-2 byproducts, such as acetaldehyde, ethylene, and acetone, were not produced during the reaction, while only methane and carbon monoxide were generated from the reaction. Selectivity for methane was in the range 7% to 14%, and selectivity for carbon monoxide was in the range 5% to 8%. Interestingly, when Co–10 K/Al2O3–CaO catalyst was used, the selectivity of methane was lowest, thus suggesting that methane selectivity was closely related to hydrogen yield. Therefore, further experiments were carried out, in order to investigate the effect of potassium on methane formation. 3.7 Methanation reaction of carbon monoxide and hydrogen Regardless of the type of catalyst used, byproducts, such as carbon monoxide and methane, are produced during ethanol steam reforming. In particular, the main reason for low hydrogen yield is the production of methane. One mole of hydrogen can be generated from carbon monoxide (CO + H2O → CO2 + H2), while four moles of hydrogen can be produced from methane (CH4 + 2H2O → CO2 + 4H2). Also, methane is very stable compound, and steam reforming of methane requires higher temperature than ethanol. Therefore, suppressing the formation of methane is very significant for achieving high yield of hydrogen in the steam reforming of ethanol. Methane can be produced from the direct decomposition of acetate species (reaction intermediate) or methanation of CO [40]. In particular, the methanation of CO consumes hydrogen (CO + 2H2 → CH4 + H2O), so it should be inhibited, in order to retain high yield of hydrogen. Table 5 presents the catalytic performance of Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO (x = (0, 5, 10, and 15)) catalysts in the methanation reaction of carbon monoxide and hydrogen at 450 °C. It was clearly shown that compared to the unpromoted catalyst, K-doped catalysts demonstrated completely different catalytic performance. After potassium introduction, both CO conversion and methane yield decreased, and large amount of coke was formed. According to the literature, CO adsorbs linearly on the surface metal sites of catalysts. However, after potassium doping, the adsorption state of CO changes to bridged state, which becomes more stable [19,41,42]. Methanation of CO proceeds via a 2-step process. First, disproportionation of CO occurs, and then hydrogenation of the carbon generated from the previous reaction takes place [19,41,42]. When potassium is present, disproportionation and the subsequent hydrogenation of carbon species are suppressed, because the adsorption state of CO changes to bridged state [19,41,42]. Combining the results of Table 5 and previous reports, it can be concluded that potassium inhibited both the disproportionation of CO, and the hydrogenation of carbon species. Table 5 shows that as potassium loading increased to 15 wt.%, methane yield decreased from 81% to 10%, while CO conversion decreased from 87% to 62%. Hence, it was clear that after potassium doping, methane yield decreased more drastically than CO conversion, implying that the effect of potassium was more critical in the second step of the reaction. In conclusion, potassium enhanced hydrogen yield in ethanol steam reforming by inhibiting the formation of methane. 4 Conclusion A series of K-promoted cobalt catalysts supported on Al2O3–CaO xerogel supports with various K loading were prepared by an epoxide-driven sol–gel method and a subsequent wetness impregnation method. The catalysts were applied to the steam reforming of ethanol for hydrogen production. All catalysts showed stable catalytic performance for 1,000 min reaction, because acidic sites of alumina were neutralized by alkali or alkaline earth metal. Higher hydrogen yield could be obtained using K-promoted catalysts, and byproduct, especially methane formation, was low, compared to when using the unpromoted catalyst. The promotion effect of K on the steam reforming of ethanol was investigated by various characterizations. After applying the catalysts to methanation reaction, it was revealed that low methane selectivity was caused by the suppression effect of K on the methanation reaction. Also, TPSR analysis showed that after K doping, the initiation temperature of the steam reforming of ethanol could be shifted to lower temperature. However, excess amount of K doping blocked small pores of the alumina–calcium support, which resulted in the loss of surface area and pore volume of the catalysts. In addition, XPS analysis revealed that as the amount of K doping increased, the surface concentration of cobalt decreased. Therefore, optimum loading existed for the ethanol steam reforming; and among the K-promoted catalysts, Co–10 K/Al2O3–CaO catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: A series of K-promoted cobalt catalysts supported on Al2O3–CaO xerogel supports with different K loading (Co–xK/Al2O3–CaO, x = 0, 5, 10, and 15 wt.%, at fixed Co loading of 15 wt.%) were prepared to apply for ethanol steam reforming (ESR). K-promoted catalysts showed higher hydrogen yield and lower methane selectivity than did unpromoted catalyst. The promotion effect of K was investigated using various analyses, such as N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray Diffraction (XRD), H2–Temperature-Programmed Reduction (H2–TPR), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and Temperature-Programmed Surface Reaction (TPSR). Also, the catalysts were applied to methanation reaction, which is the main undesired reaction. It was found that lower methane selectivity during ESR over K-promoted catalysts was explained by the suppression effect of K on the methanation reaction. Also, TPSR study revealed that after K doping, starting temperature of the ESR shifted to lower temperature. However, excess amount of K doping blocked small pores of the alumina–calcium support, resulting in deterioration of the textural property of the catalysts. In addition, XPS analysis showed that as the amount of K doping increased, amount of surface concentration of cobalt decreased. Therefore, 10 wt.% K was found to be optimum loading for the ESR.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogen production by the steam reforming of ethanol over K-promoted Co/Al2O3–CaO xerogel catalysts
